Oldsmar, Florida 34677

CERTIFICATION STATEMENT



To the best of the undersigned?s knowledge, information, and belief formed after 
reasonable inquiry, the information submitted is true, accurate, and complete.




__________________________            Patrick Nailos
Signature                        Print Name



Wastewater Facilities Supervisor            May 10, 2004
Title                        Date










EXECUTIVE SUMMARY ELEMENTS



Accidental Release Prevention & Emergency Response Policies

    Accidental Release Prevention:

All areas of release prevention for The City of Oldsmar Wastewater Facility are 
contained in the City?s Process Safety Management Program (PSM). This is a 
comprehensive plan that encompasses all aspects of the City of Oldsmar?s WWF 
methods and procedures of receiving, handling, processing and worst as well as 
alternative accidental release scenarios of hazardous chemicals on site. 


    Emergency response Policies:

The City of Oldsmar Wastewater Facility?s response to emergencies is controlled 
by 4 main elements/policies: 

> Risk Management Plan
> Process Safety Management
> Chlorine Emergency Response Action Plan
> Sulfur Dioxide Emergency Response Action Plan



The management of the City of Oldsmar?s Wastewater Facility has had a safety 
program in effect since 1991. Since inception, the program has undergone 
extensive change. The evolution process has taken this program from the early 
planning, research and development stages to a well defined, structured and to 
this date, safe & successful program. This is evidenced by a track record with 
respect to ?employee time lost? and ?vehicle time lost, accident? awards 
received from the National Safety Council. This years? requirement for the RMP, 
PSM, and other accompanying plans provide an opportunity to update, re

vise and 
in some cases create the necessary plans needed to assure the ultimate in safety 
for both employees and surrounding residents. 







Regulated Substances Handled

> Chlorine (Cl2)???????????????up to 6000 lbs.
> Sulfur Dioxide (SO2)????????????.up to 6000 lbs.



The City of Oldsmar?s Wastewater Facility is located at 351 Lafayette Boulevard 
has a primary function to receive, treat, and dispose of sanitary sewage. The 
treated effluent is discharged to Mobbley Bay or sold as reclaimed water to 
residents of the City. 

Chlorine is used in the wastewater treatment process to remove harmful bacteria 
in the water, as required by FDEP/EPA regulations, prior to discharge into 
Mobbley Bay or into the reclaimed distribution system.

Sulfur Dioxide is used in the wastewater treatment process for the 
dechlorination of Plant effluent, prior to discharge into Mobbley Bay. This 
effluent dechlorination process is required in order to avoid a negative impact 
to the flora and fauna in the surrounding surface waters.

Both of these processes occur in the same building, identified to as the 
?Chlorine Building?. This building is located at the southernmost side of the 
Wastewater Facility.





Worst-Case Release Scenario and the Alternative Release Scenario(s)
The following data provided by O?Brien & Gere Engineers, Inc. 


Worst-Case Release Scenario Calculations
Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide Systems
City of Oldsmar 
4/28/99
Chlorine
Total quantity in cylinder = 2,000 lb.
Release Rate = (2,000 lb./10 min)*0.55 (enclosed space factor) = 110 lb/min

From Table 11 (RMP Guidance Manual):

100 lb/min, distance to toxic endpoint = 0.9 mi.
150 lb/min, distance to toxic endpoint = 1.2 mi.

Interpolating between them:

100 lb/min    0.9 mi.
110 lb/min    d
150 lb/min    1.2 mi.

1) 100-110/100-150 = 0.9-d/0.9-1.2 
2) -10/-50 = 0.9-d/-0.3
3) 3 = -45+50d
4) 48=50d
5) d=48/50

d = 0.96 miles (for urban terrain)


Sulfur Dioxide
Total quantity in cylinder = 2,000 lb.
Release Rate = 110

lb/min
 
From Table 12 (RMP Guidance Manual):

100 lb/min, distance to toxic endpoint = 0.9 mi.
150 lb/min, distance to toxic endpoint = 1.1 mi.

d = 0.94 miles (urban terrain)







RMP* Comp
Results of Consequence Analysis

Chemical: Chlorine
CAS #: 7782-50-5
Category: Toxic Gas
Scenario: Alternative
Release Duration: 10 minutes
Storage Parameters: Hole or puncture area: 0.049 square inches
Tank Pressure: 92.5 psi
Tank Temp: 770 F

Release Rate: 4.19 pounds per min
Mitigation Measures: Release in enclosed space, in direct contact with outside 
air

Topography: Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)
Toxic Endpoint: 0.0087 mg/L; basis: ERPG-2
Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint: <0.1 miles (<0.16 kilometers); report as 
0.1 mile

--------Assumptions About This Scenario---------
Wind Speed: 3 meters/second (6.7 miles/hour)
Stability Class: D
Air Temperature: 77 degrees F (25 degrees C)
------------------------------------------------

y of Oldsmar?s Process Safety Management Guide

Five-Year Accident History

There is no data regarding the Five-Year Accident History. In the past five 
years there have been no accidents to report.



Emergency Response Program

Refer to: PSM (Chlorine ERP and Sulfur Dioxide ERP)



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Greater communication between safety officials and employees is and will 
continue to be the key to greater safety. Through monthly safety meetings, which 
focus on all aspects of safety, all employees are continually reminded of 
potential disaster and how to avoid it. 

As new ?state of the art? products are developed, they will be considered, and 
if appropriate, purchased by the respective divisions. 

Any new programs such as the RMP will in fact be our biggest ?Planned changes? 
to our Safety Program. Whereas our Safety Program is gradually evolving into an 
efficient and highly functional program, minor refining is all that is currently 
planned for the upcoming years. The current system proves to be functioning 
quite well and will continue to change with the times, as well as keep up with 
the ever-changing industry standards.
